scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The collection contains 83 manuscripts of works by Dreiser including his novel Jennie Gerhardt;short essays, chiefly biographical sketches; poems; stories; interviews; miscellaneous pieces; and galley proofs of An American Tragedy.

Essay topics include William Archer, Philip Armour, Katherine Bloodgood, John Burroughs, Joseph H. Choate, H. Barringer Cox, Louise Cox, Edward Croarkin, Chauncey Depew, William De Morgan, Frank E. Elwell, Louis Fagan, Frank Fowler, Gilbert Gane, Frank Wakely Gunsaulus, Moses Handy, William Dean Howells, John LaFarage, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, Lillian Nordica, Horace Pingree, Maria Louise Pool, George M. Pullman, Thomas B. Reed, Bayard Taylor, the University of Chicago, J. Q. A. Ward, modern business men, the University of Chicago, The American Museum of Natural History, Armour Institute, American women composers, artists, dramatists, and poets, Brandywine, Cedermere, Cramp Ship Yards, and lynching.

Correspondence discusses his writing, publication efforts, critical reaction, censorship, legal suits with publishers, (John Lane Company) and his personal life including friendships, romances and travel.

Specific topics include early editorial work, the publication of Sister Carrie,The Titan,and The Geniusin an era of censorship; suppression of "The Genius"; copyright problems; a possible dramatization of Sister Carrie;a French translation and a film version of "An American Tragedy"; a hiking trip from Georgia to New Jersey; African-Americans in Savannah; Walt Whitman and Mark Twain; religious views; role of the Author's League of America; dislike of film version of An American Tragedy; Norman Duncan; the Fortean Society; respect for Lenin and Trotsky; Caldwell's Tobacco Road.
Miscellaneous material includes the Anti-Vice Commission report on The Genius;promotional pamphlets; and clippings pertaining to Dreiser.

did.unittitle: Letters
Theodore Dreiser to Duffy 1898 Aug 24

scopecontent.p: Hopes he will like the poem; writes that it could be illustrated; wishes Duffy would look at Dreiser's poem in the September Success; wants his signature.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Duffy 1905 Mar 21

scopecontent.p: Needs humorous jokes for new magazine, Smith's, published by the publishers of Ainslee's; offers usual rate for submissions.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to [Edna] Kenton 1905 May 6

scopecontent.p: Thanks for her kind words; writes that Sister Carrieis still in the doldrums, though the general situation is better; mentions that book is well known; owns plates and hopes to find publisher for them; thinks he met her in 1892 in Chicago while peddling books; calls himself older and wiser, but no less radical, simply sorrowful and uncertain.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Sidney Portier 1907 Dec 31

scopecontent.p: Writes that 3 weeks before seeing his stories has turned into 3 months and that it is time he had a look at the first of them.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to [William] C. Lengel 1911 Oct 15

scopecontent.p: Writes in "A Letter About Himself," that Harper has 2 books of his letters and clippings and he has more letters from critics and editor; mentions he is in Who's Who, his favorite book, his characteristics, his books issued and those suppressed, and his wish to be rich.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to [Franklin P.] Adams 1911 Oct 30

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his kind words; remembers his sincere approval of Sister Carrieand Jennie Gerhardt

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, S. S. Mauretania to Edna Kenton 1911 Nov 22

scopecontent.p: Writes that her faith and kind words will never be forgotten.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to [Pauline] Hemmerde 1911 Dec 30

scopecontent.p: Thanks her for post-impressionist book and the Boredecker; waives Songs of the Northuntil her returns from Italy, since all he can do now is stick it in his trunk; writes it will be safe with the publisher.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, London, to Pauline Hemmerde 1912 Jan 9

scopecontent.p: Asks her to buy a box of the same cigarettes she bought at Christmas to give to [Grant] Richards and charge them to his account.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Rider 1912 Nov 7

scopecontent.p: Mails him The Financier, writes that he does not expect him to read it, rather it is for his autograph shelf.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Charles V. E. Starrett 1913 Jun 12

scopecontent.p: Includes typescript and carbon typescript copeis; thanks him and Press Writer's Club for letter requesting advice and cheer; discusses qualities of new great writers at length; quotes Sidney Lanier.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to [Albert] Mordell 1913 Sep 25

scopecontent.p: Expresses pleasure at receiving his letter; writes that Mordell's book made a deep impression on many; welcomes a critical intellect; finds himself to have few literary prejudices, though not many literary favorites; hopes to discuss The Financier, volume one of A Triology of Desire; writes that The Titanand The Stoicwill be volumes 2 and 3; expressed pleasure that Mordell likes Jennie Gerhardtas most critics perfer Sister Carrie; mentions William Marion Reedy and Thomas B. Mosten, Smart Set, The Century, A Traveller at 40; plans to publish The Titanin Harper's.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1913 Oct 21

scopecontent.p: Inquires about the law and the profits of book; feels pressured to complete The Titan; mentions Strindberg interview.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1913 Nov 5

scopecontent.p: Expresses pleasure with the opinion of his lawyer friend; feels time will justify him for The Financier and 2 succeeding volumes.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Phliadelphia 1913 Nov 5

scopecontent.p: Asks Mordell to call him or write; gives address as 23 W. 58 St.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1913 Dec 1

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for galleys; calls article intelligent; complains of misrepresentation in The Sunand The Times; decides not to be interviewed any more as he is tired of literary mush; call New York papers the worst.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1913 Dec 4

scopecontent.p: Asks him to get 10 copies of an interview when it appears; calls the interview intelligent and would like to keep it for future reference.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1913 Dec 9

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for review and interview; asks him to send 8-9 copies of interview.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1914 Feb 18

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for clipping; intends to send copy of The Titanwhen it comes out.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, Chicago, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1914 Mar 6

scopecontent.p: Writes that Harper's has decided not to publish The Titanafter printing 10,000 copies; plans to issue book through one of several firms; calls it Sister Carrieall over again.

did.unittitle: H. L. Mencken, Baltimore, to Theodore Dreiser, New York [1914] Mar 23

scopecontent.p: Writes that he has completed The Titan; calls it the best thing he has ever done with the exception of Jennie Gerhardt, which had more emotional appeal; mentions A Traveller at 40, Baltimore Sun, and the Century Co.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Mr. Rethy, Philadelphia 1914 Apr 18

scopecontent.p: Comments that he has nothing to add to former letter; mentions The Internationaland The Manes; likes Rethy's poem.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1914 May 4

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for books; expects to receive books from Lane this week; intends to send one to Mordell.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1914 Jun 9

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his services in connection with Brandes, wishes he would read enclosed statement in regard to condition brought about by Mitchell Kennedy regarding John Lane and himself; believes statement illuminates American publishers publishing methods.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1914 Jun 22

scopecontent.p: Writes that he is not troubled by wrathful reviews; believes that neither praise nor blame settle the fate of anything for more than a little while; encloses review, which he finds amusing.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1914 Dec 24

scopecontent.p: Expresses interest in points made in lecture; presumes Mordell wrote clipping in Philadelphia Recordwhich H. L. Mencken sent to him; asks for copies of page on which it appears; mentions speaking engagement.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1914 Dec 26

scopecontent.p: Requests copies of Recordto be sent to Malden in Hudson, New York

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1915 Jan 14

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for clippings; mentions [John Cowper Powys], and a lecture he will present in Chicago

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1915 Apr 28
Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1915 May 6

scopecontent.p: Writes The Geniuswill not be out until August and he will see that he gets a copy.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1915 May 13

scopecontent.p: Owns rights to Sister Carrie; asks him to act as his attorney in the matter; intends to ask Hayer what is expected for Jennie Gerhardt, which is a similar case.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1915 May 12

scopecontent.p: Believes paying $75 for an offense of this kind is to invite copyright stealing; writes that nothing of the kind will be done and that Harper'swill proceed unless favorable adjustment is reached; mentions The Jewish World, fee to Mordell.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1915 May 19

scopecontent.p: Resents change of name as he owns copyright and plates, states that if a $60,000 loss can be afforded, $500 ought not to bother them; mentions Harper's ownership of right to present selling edition.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1915 Sep 24

scopecontent.p: Sends bill

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1915 Oct 31

scopecontent.p: Discusses The Genius; mentions New York Globe; thinks he is entitled to indicate thoughts of characters in their own language.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1915 Nov 28

scopecontent.p: Believes he will assume art and literary direction of a large film corporation; opens himself to suggestions concerning plays, books, legends, etc., that could be scenarios; seeks subject of distinction, true drama, and poignance; promises to reward Mordell for any ideas of value.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1915 Nov 30

scopecontent.p: Asks for a few preliminary suggestions so Dreiser may catch the drift of his mind and taste.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Albert Mordell 1916 Jan 19

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for Ms. Skidelsky's review; states that she is all wrong about The Titan; calls it the best book he has ever done; mentions H. L. Mencken, trip to Savannah; requests guess of how many copies of The Geniushave been sold in Philadelphia.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser to Little 1916 Jan 28

scopecontent.p: Discusses review of Maughan's Of Human Bondage; sends thanks; asserts that they are blessed to be able to enthuse over anything openly.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, Savannah, Georgia, to Willard Dillman, Minneapolis 1916 Feb 7

scopecontent.p: Complains of grippe, which has caused him to leave New York; undertakes unpleasantly large business; finds Dillman's letter sincere and entertainingly philosophic; comments that people who think logically and incisively are rare; marvels at how cleverly the world is run based on tradition and precept; writes that he does not know if the world is getting better or worse; comments that the world improves mechanically and is virtually static and that love is not rewarded nor hate punished; comments on himself, psuedo intellectuals, and laborers; hopes to see him sometime in Savannah.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, Savannah, to Willard Dillmann, Minneapolis 1916 Mar 9

scopecontent.p: Puts friendship and affection before anything else; welcomes him as a friend; leans to anyone who approaches him via regard; mentions Savannah's Black population; calls them respectful, docile, and clean, which is more than he can say of the poor of other races; wishes for him to get a copy of Plays of the Natural and Supernaturaland tell Dresier what he thinks of it.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Mayan [Little] 1916 Jun 21

scopecontent.p: Requests that first chapter be sent without waiting to finish all 3 copies of remaining chapters; needs to get them to H. L. Mencken at the earliest date; wishes he would write John Cowper Powys and suggest "Cowperwood" is legitimately spelled "Cooperwood."

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Willard Dillman 1916 Jul 31

scopecontent.p: Expresses pleasure at receiving Dillman's letter regarding Dreiser's plays, not because he agreed, but because he was forthright; fancies he should stick to novels, despite his former intentions to write a few 3 or 4 act plays; works hard, but not always in New York; considers going on a trip from Denver west with a friend and will stop off in Minneapolis if he does; cheers the Anti-Vice Society for suppressing The Genius, which is already done save for prosecution, which will occur if any more copies are sold; states that John Lane Co. will fight, but may already be beaten by the Puritan courts; asserts that his work will be viewed with care from now on.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Mayan [Little] 1916 Aug 1

scopecontent.p: Expresses gratitude for copies of vice charges; wishes he would spread news of suppression of The Genius as widely as possible; want to put Lane Co. where they will have to fight, whether they want to or not.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1916 Dec 13

scopecontent.p: Approves interview if he lets Dreiser go over the manuscript proofs beforehand; states that his corrections are seldom heeded when corrects only proofs.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, To Willard Dillman, Minneapolis 1917 Jan 11

scopecontent.p: Expresses pleasure that Dillman likes A Hoosier Holiday; finds comment about his return to Catholicism amusing; denies idea that Catholics return to Catholicism; states that his present faculties will have to change if he is to return to Catholicism on his deathbed as it is claimed Voltaire did.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell 1917 Apr 4

scopecontent.p: Explains that he and Lane Co. are not on the best terms at present, but they may claim Dreiser advised them to send document which Dreiser has not had time to read over.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1917 Aug 22

scopecontent.p: Discusses case regarding The Genius, which is before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court; states that his counsel, Standfield & Levy, have a brief on his behalf and John Lane Co., whom he is suing to compel them to fulfill contract and publish The Genius, have filed a brief in reply; writes that Joseph S. Auerbach has been called into the case by Standfield & Levy to argue the case after October 1; sends brief.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1917 Sep 11

scopecontent.p: Like article, but does not think he should publish everything he learns in private; requests 20 copies of papers in question, as the lawyers can use them.

did.unittitle: Edward H. Smith of Monday World, New York, to Theodore Dreiser 1918 Feb 24

scopecontent.p: Suggests a banquet for him the evening after the decision in The Geniuscase is handed down; lists possible guests; requests Dreiser's consent; offers alternative of dinner for American Literary that Liberalism with Dreiser as guest of honor; suggests publicity idea for The Geniusinvolving K. K. Kitchen, Puritanism, Comstockism, and Anti-Puritanic ideas; suggests that Dreiser communicate with his lawyers and publishers.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Willard Dillman, Minneapolis 1918 Apr 23

scopecontent.p: Believes Lavinsky(?) is a good piece of realism and wishes he might write 6 books like it; intends to join Willard on trip to New Orleans and towards the gulf; mentions his 1910 separation from his wife; wants to figure out expenses so they can split costs; thinks September would be the perfect time to begin traveling.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to [Frank] Harris 1918 May 11

scopecontent.p: Writes that he will meet him anytime; suggests he come to dinner at a quiet spot.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, Havre de Grace, Maryland, to Willard Dillman, Minneapolis 1918 May 30

scopecontent.p: Writes that he has been in the woods eating and working and the air makes him sleepy; plans to work in the city, as he requires typing services there; expresses interest in Mississippi trip; plans to take Dillman up on offer to visit "Excelsior."

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to [Frank] Harris 1918 Jun 5

scopecontent.p: Encloses manuscript of an essay disguised as a posthumous autobiography; wants his opinion; believes the manuscript too different for any American publisher.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, Havre de Grace, Maryland to [Frank Harris] 1918 Jun 7
did.physdesc: ALS, 1 p., w/ postcard to Dreiser

scopecontent.p: Sends sketch; mentions that he has been complimented on his speaking ability; includes advertising card for "Theodore Dreiser: America's Greatest Novelist," a lecture by Andre Tredon.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, Havre de Grace, Maryland, to [Frank] Harris 1918 Jun 17

scopecontent.p: Hopes to write out Sister Carrieincident and points in connection with his philosophy; explains that Hey, Rub-a-Dubshould not be assumed to represent his mental state; mentions 1911-1912 visit to Europe, which he recorded in A Traveller at 40; discusses Whitman, Twain, Huckleberry Finn, Tom Sawyer

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to [Frank] Harris 1918 Jul 5

scopecontent.p: Sends writing to clarify his viewpoint; mentions "Man and Romance."

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to [Frank] Harris 1918 Jul 10

scopecontent.p: Finds his piece impressive; sends "Personality," which may have a place in his magazine.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Willard Dillman, Minneapolis 1918 Aug 29

scopecontent.p: Offers to pay bulk of expenses to make September 15 trip possible; feels tied down with long promised work; writes that he has looked for an artist to join them on the trip.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Henry Eastman Lower, Washington 1918 Nov 13

scopecontent.p: Suggests he paste this letter in his book and send book for Dreiser to autograph; includes copies of Life Art and Americain an upcoming volume of essays and has no copies of it.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1919 Feb 25

scopecontent.p: Tells him to write Rusy and start a discussion without mentioning Dreiser.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to [Eva] Jacoby, Hurleyville, New York 1919 Jun 8

scopecontent.p: Thanks her for sympathy; writes that bump is not serious, he has 2 mending ribs and some scars; offers to sign the books she has; questions judgment of current generation.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to [Edmund] Wilson 1919 Sep 19

scopecontent.p: Sends 5 essays, writes that "Secrecy" and "Neurotic America and the Sex Impluse" may be published as they are under consideration elsewhere; hopes for an early opinion of the essay.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, Los Angeles, to Arthur Carter Hume, New York 1920 Jan 9
Theodore Dreiser, Los Angeles, to [David] Karsner 1920 Feb 18
did.physdesc: Expresses pleasure at receiving book; hopes Liveright makes him a lot of money off it; dislikes essay title, which might have been "The King is Naked."

did.unittitle: John Lane Co., New York, to Theodore Dreiser, Los Angeles 1920 Apr 26

scopecontent.p: Refers to Dreiser letter and royalty statement ending December 31, 1919 mailed several weeks ago; includes note on bottom to Arthur Carter Hume from Dreiser offering to show statements of indebtedness for books made from his movies to Hume.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, Los Angeles, to Arthur Carter Hume 1920 May 1

scopecontent.p: Discusses case regarding The Genius, mentioning John Lane Co., The New York Society for the Suppression of Vice, personal loss he has sustained; government refusal to act; encloses clipping from Cosmopolitian.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1922 Dec 12

scopecontent.p: States that the 1901 edition of Sister Carrie, of which he has several, is not very valuable; plans to be in New York until the spring.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1922 Dec 26
Rex Beach and Author's League of America, New York, to Theodore Dreiser 1923 Apr 26

scopecontent.p: Invites him to participate in proposed international congress on motion picture arts to be held in New York under auspices of Author's League of America; writes that the congress was suggested by Aldolph Zucker to formulate set of principles for artistic and cultural development of motion pictures; requests suggestions for the congress and his participation on both days.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Rex Beach, New York 1923 May 5

scopecontent.p: Explains that he does not wish to participate in developing standards for motion pictures; believes Author's League should be concerned with serious letters; mentions Clean Books Bill, religious groups who supported the bill, and Liveright.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, New York 1923 Nov 1

scopecontent.p: Writes that 5:30 today will be fine and she should ring basement bell, as Dreiser's work room is there.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Gelett Burgess, Author's League of America, New York 1923

scopecontent.p: Asserts that Author's League has not assisted author's or publishers under attack from censorship; Burgess states that Dreiser is not aware of the work of the League; mentions Clean Books Bill, Liveright, The Genius, Motion Picture Conference, New York newspapers, Harelock Ellis, D. H. Lawrence, and Emile Zola.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1924 Jan 10

scopecontent.p: Asks if he is in touch with Philadelphia bookstores to get account of how many copies of new issue of The Geniussold before January 1; wants to check on statement.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to W. Orton Tewson, New York 1924 Jul 22

scopecontent.p: Discusses luncheon and possibility of publishing what was there.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1924 Aug 4

scopecontent.p: Wants to undertake matter spoke of; inquires when proceedings can begin and how to go about it.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to W. Orton Tewson, editor, Saturday Evening Post1924 Aug 12

scopecontent.p: Writes that he does no have an essay and cannot review a book; intends to submit poems, if a page could be given a them; suggest $35 for poems.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to Albert Mordell, Philadelphia 1924 Aug 13

scopecontent.p: Wants to proceed at his convenience; believes he may have to live in Philadelphia.

did.unittitle: W. Orton Tewson, New York, to Theodore Dreiser 1924 Aug 15

scopecontent.p: Likes his idea of page feature for a group of his poems; asks him to send poems; suggests having artist work up a frame to make it stand out.

did.unittitle: Theodore Dreiser, New York, to W. Orton Tewson 1924 Aug 16
Theodore Dreiser to W. Orton Tewson 1924 Sep 1
